title: 107_hr2475
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fair Disbursement of Offshore Oil Revenue Act of 2001". The Congress acknowledges the increasing demand for energy in the US, declining domestic oil and gas production, overreliance on foreign sources, the need to develop oil and gas resources in the Outer Continental Shelf, potential impacts on State and local governments, and the importance of sharing revenues with coastal States and counties. The Congress acknowledges the need to develop oil and gas resources in the Outer Continental Shelf and the importance of sharing revenues with coastal States and counties. The Congress acknowledges the need to develop oil and gas resources in the Outer Continental Shelf and the importance of sharing revenues with coastal States and counties. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "coastal State," "coastal county," "coast line," "Outer Continental Shelf," "Secretary," and "revenues." The term "revenues" refers to all money collected under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, including bonuses, rents, royalties, and interest. SEC. 4. COASTAL COMMUNITIES OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF RECEIPT FUND. Establishment of the Coastal Communities Outer Continental Shelf Receipt Fund in the Treasury of the United States to receive revenues from Outer Continental Shelf leases within 200 miles of the coast. The Secretary is responsible for payments into the Fund starting in fiscal year 2002, with adjustments allowed for errors and discrepancies. New revenues under leases are subject to specific conditions outlined in the legislation. The Coastal Communities Outer Continental Shelf Receipt Fund was established to receive revenues from leases within 200 miles of the coast. The Secretary is responsible for payments into the Fund starting in fiscal year 2002. Specific conditions apply to new revenues under leases, including royalty revenues and other revenues based on lease issuance dates. The Coastal Communities Outer Continental Shelf Receipt Fund was established to receive revenues from leases within 200 miles of the coast. The Secretary is responsible for payments into the Fund starting in fiscal year 2002. Specific conditions apply to new revenues under leases, including royalty revenues and other revenues based on lease issuance dates. SEC. 5. DISPOSITION OF FUND. The Secretary pays half of revenues from the Fund to coastal States annually, based on their attributable interest. Boundaries between States are determined 200 miles offshore, following judicial decrees or international law principles. Before receiving funds under this subsection, each coastal State must enact legislation to provide permits for onshore facilities supporting offshore oil or gas development. Failure to do so will result in funds not being disbursed, and the Secretary will consider this before offering additional leases. Coastal counties within the State will receive half of the revenues from the Fund at the same time as the coastal States. The Secretary shall pay coastal counties half of the revenues and interest earned from the Fund, based on delineated lateral boundaries 200 miles seaward. Boundaries follow existing county boundaries and lease lines, prioritizing size consistency. The coastal county's share of funds is determined by a formula considering its coastline and population compared to the state's total. Before receiving funds, each coastal county must enact a statute or ordinance annually. Each coastal county must annually enact legislation to provide permits for onshore facilities supporting offshore oil or gas development. Failure to do so will result in funds not being disbursed, and the Secretary will consider this before offering additional leases. Coastal States must use funds for administrative costs, environmental projects, and natural resources as determined by the State. Each coastal county must allocate funds to local communities based on proximity to the coast, withholding funds from communities that fail to issue permits for onshore facilities supporting offshore oil or gas development. The Secretary, in consultation with coastal State Governors, designates coastal counties for the Act's purposes. Boundaries set under section 5 are only for this Act.
